C. Role-based access

Role-based access control (RBAC) is the best preventative control to ensure that database integrity is maintained. RBAC restricts access to the database based on users' roles and responsibilities within an organization. It ensures that users only have access to the data and functions that are necessary for their job functions, preventing unauthorized access and potential data breaches. RBAC is a fundamental security principle in database management and helps in maintaining data integrity by limiting access to authorized users and roles.

When using data analytics to perform an audit, the IS auditor should first define the data needs. This involves understanding the audit objectives and determining what data is required to meet those objectives. Defining the data needs sets the foundation for the subsequent steps in the data analytics process, as it guides the auditor in identifying which data to collect and how to analyze it.

By defining data needs first, the IS auditor establishes a clear direction for the entire data analytics process, ensuring they gather the right information, use appropriate techniques, and ultimately derive valuable audit insights.

A. coordinate disaster recovery administration with the outsourcing vendor

When an organization outsources its Information Systems (IS) functions, it still retains responsibility for ensuring that critical functions like disaster recovery are adequately addressed. Option A, coordinating disaster recovery administration with the outsourcing vendor, is the most appropriate choice in this context.

Options B and C involve delegating the evaluation of disaster recovery to third parties (either a third-party vendor or internal audit), which can be part of the overall disaster recovery strategy but doesn't absolve the organization of its primary responsibility for disaster recovery planning and execution.

Option D, discontinuing maintenance of the disaster recovery plan (DRP), is not a responsible choice because disaster recovery planning is crucial for business continuity and risk mitigation, and it should not be abandoned, especially when IT functions are outsourced.
